**Chapter IV**

“You might remember—yeah, I told you before,” Svidrigaïlov started, “that I was stuck in debtors’ prison here, drowning in a huge amount of debt, with no way to pay it off. No need to get into how Marfa Petrovna bailed me out. But can you believe how crazy a woman can get when she loves? She was a good person, really sensible, even if she had no formal education. 

You wouldn’t believe it, but after a ton of dramatic scenes and her losing it over jealousy, she actually agreed to a sort of deal with me that lasted our whole marriage. She was way older than me and always had a clove or something in her mouth. I had enough honesty (and a bit of swinishness) to tell her straight up that I couldn’t promise to be totally faithful. This confession drove her wild, but weirdly, she seemed to appreciate my brutal honesty. For a jealous woman, knowing upfront was a big deal. 

After a lot of tears, we made an unwritten contract: first, I would never leave Marfa Petrovna and would always be her husband; second, I wouldn’t disappear without her say-so; third, I wouldn’t take on a permanent mistress; and fourth, in return for…”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Svidrigaïlov recounts the unconventional contract he made with his wife, Marfa Petrovna, regarding fidelity and their marriage dynamics.
